十几年前的游戏了，那会儿还是在小学，只能借着领居家的电脑玩几次，这在当时是很不错的游戏，得过很多大奖，现在看来，也有可玩性。

Tips：以下内容含剧透。

战役模式中，一共有10个关卡，前九个关卡每次都可以从5个神当中选择一个来侍奉，然后开局就会得到该神的一个技能。这样就增加了游戏的不确定性，技能多样，结局也多变，即使你每次都选择同一个神，但是到最后选了其他的神，那结局同样会反转，相当于你背叛了之前的神。。。

最喜欢买的还是在第三个关卡选择土神，他的领地有条龙，这条龙让他很头疼，记住，你别直接去打死这条龙，而是去亵渎另一个法师的总坛，亵渎之后会得到这条龙（五个魂级的怪）。。。在游戏初期，你只要召唤两三个魔法兵，再带着这条龙就可以横着走了，期间注意自己别死了，然后多留意一下龙的血条，别离得太远，否则加血加不上。

最后一个关卡是终极BOSS----先知（也叫作马杜克），他是真心变态，可以吸收你的魂，也能召唤所有五个魂级的怪，还能使用所有系列的终极魔法。打完之后会有很长的一段结束CG，顺便说一句，那个四脚怪真的很搞笑，居然会抢镜。。。

39490112.review:
Awesome little gem from the past.

Sacrifice is an TPP spellcasting action/RTS hybrid. You are wandering mage, who fled his destroyed world and entered a realm of squabbling gods. Each of them welcomes you with open arms, and tries to use you to undermine the other gods by battling their champions.

In the actual game you summon various units and command them in the battlefield, you also cast spells on your enemies. Depending on the deities you join forces with you may be able to summon ents, dragons, demons, beasts made of rocks or flying monstrosities. You will be able to create an erupting volcano, summon a tornado or Death itself to kill anything and anyone on the battlefield. As an added bonus you will be able to burn your enemies with a fiery dragon, bombard them with great boulders from the sky or simply make their intestines explode. Fun!

In order to summon all these fantastic beasts and cast those fearsome spells, you will need mana - to replenish it, you will have to seize control of mana fountains scattered around the map. In order to summon your minions you will also need souls. You will start off having some, and you can collect the souls of your fallen soldiers. You can also use the souls of your dead enemies - but you need to purge them first. Summon a wicked witchdoctor, who will suck out the soul of the dead body with a giant syringe and carry it to your altar, where it will be tortured until it breaks and joins your side. Be wary tho, your altar is a great source of power, but also a great vulnerability - if your opponents desecrate it and kill you while doing so, you will be banished from this realm.

The game sports a campaign that allows you to get familiar with the units, controls,m tactics and strategies, but the AI is not very demanding - the winning strategy is to mostly hunker down near your own mana fountains and let your enemies bleed souls with each attack they launch at you. Still, the campaign is enjoyable, and completing it allows you to freely build your unit and spell selection for multiplayer matches.

As you probably already noticed, the game also sports a multiplayer mode. The battles are hectic and difficult, almost as difficult as finding opponents online. Strongly suggest playing with friends. Nontheless I think that this mode is the core of the game, and the games depth allows for a lot of learning and getting better to kick your firends' buttocks.

I must mention the style and aesthetics of the game. While the numbers of polygons and texture resolutions did not age well - obviously, considering the age of the title - the style is superb. The mix of grim and gory elements with a wicked sense of humor makes a very tasty cocktail. I would love to see this game remastered with current hardware!

If you don't mind dated graphics, enjoy an interesting aesthetic and style and are curious of an action/RTS hybrid about maintaining control of the map, get this game. It's really cool, and really cheap.

37018506.review:
El juego es excelente, mezcla componentes de rpg y estrategia. 

   En su modo campaña sos un hechicero que huye de un mundo destruido por un demonio que convocaste para destruir a tus rivales. Llegas a un nuevo mundo donde los dioses se disputan el poder y vos decidis a quien ayudar en cada misión, marcando el rumbo de la historia y consiguiendo invocaciones y hechizos por parte del dios que elegis.

   En su modo multijugador, la jugabilidad es la misma, podes elegir la lista completa de un dios en concreto o usar tu partida del modo campaña con la lista mezclada de dioses que hayas elegido, logrando diferentes combinaciones de poderes e invocaciones.

   En cuanto al juego, sos un hechicero con varios hechizos e invocaciones que vas desbloqueando al subir niveles o avanzar en la campaña. Controlas un ejercito con dichas invocaciones, asignandole formaciones y dando ordenes a grupos o unidades sueltas. Para crear ejercitos más numerosos o compuestos por unidades más fuertes es necesario convertir las almas de tus enemigos caídos. Cada jugador dispone de un altar principal, el cual se puede destruir mediante un ritual perdiendo así la partida. Luego hay varias estructuras a lo largo del mapa en las que se pueden crear fuentes de maná o templos para convertir más rápido las almas, ya que el "medico brujo" las recoje en el campo de batalla y va a pie hasta el templo o altar más cercano.

   Para su época le doy un 10/10, hoy en día se queda bastante atrás en cuanto a gráficos y la jugabilidad podría mejorarse, principalmente la interfaz de usuario.

36006055.review:
Nostro - elorum - mastadok - eliel - vermithrax - kinketsu - animus - saxo - verata - dominae - vas

...

Ahem, sorry.  Sacrifice is an exceptional RTS with a fun and entertaining story.  Each level you choose a god to work for.  Your wizard gets spells and units from that god that are yours to keep, so each playthrough can yield different units/spells based on your choices.  As you progress some gods will become offended and stop offering you work.

Your wizard is active on the battlefield along with your units.  Units are summoned with souls.  When friendly units die their souls can be easily recaptured by their wizard, or converted to a hostile wizard with some effort.  This caps the total number of units and makes each fight a potential boon or loss to your pool of souls.  There are a couple structures that can be built for the purpose of generating mana, defense, and movement.  These can only be placed at certain locations and require units if using for defense.

All-in-all, this is still one of the best, most unique games I've played.

34173318.review:
This is my favourite game of all time, and it's not just a nostalgic feeling, I still play with this masterpiece. It has a magical athmosphere you cannot find elsewhere, the story, the characters are so well written that I know nearly all quests by heart, yet I still replay them 'just one more time' when I get the mood for it.

The story is about a banished wizard, who enters a new realm of magical floating islands that are controlled by five gods, who constantly fight each other for justice, dominance or just fun. All gods control a sphere of natural energies which are earth, fire, air, life and death. You can choose one patron god on every level to do quests for them, and in return you get new spells to cast and creatures to summon from the chosen god's sphere. Keep in mind though, that if you serve the dark powers, you will soon lose the favor of the benelovent gods and vice versa, so choosing sides has limits according to your previous choices. All the gods have an interesting character that can always surprise you, as the good guys can become quite warlike, the bad guys may become just scared, the smart guys can act foolish and the simple guys quite resourceful, so everything and everyone turns out to be quite different than as they seemed at first.

The creatures in game are colourful and interesting, the spells you can control are ok first, but become quite powerful as you get more power, in the end you may summon volcanoes or tornadoes, or even death itself, depending on who you serve. The islands look like paradise or hell, depending on which god has control over them. On every stage every wizard get an altar, which serve as a base for them. Mana fountains are scattered across the island you play on, which can be occupied to get mana from it. The key element of gameplay however is the resource called 'soul', the more you have, the more powerful army you can summon. Yes, by using souls, you can summon creatures to fight, who will serve you until they die. If a creature falls, you can collect its soul again, but if the creature served another wizard before, you must sacrifice it on your altar first to get its soul, which means the enemy has a chance to prevent it. The key to victory is to desecrate the enemy wizard's altar: you may sacrifice one of your own creatures there, and if the enemy wizard dies during the ritual, you win. Oh yes, death is not permanent in the game until your altar stands, as you may easily resurrect yourself at a mana source.

To sum up things, gameplay is quite dinamic and fast, there are no slow base building elements, you just get a few mana sources, then you summon creatures, and the enemy is already upon you. This game mechanic is actually quite fun - even if it seems a bit difficult at first - it mixes roleplaying and tactical elements in a way no other game does. Voices and music are also amazing, graphics are still ok, and it is a big pro, considering that this game was published in 2000. 

To cut things short, if you like decent old fantasy games that were made with devotion and enthusiasm, you must try out this one, but beware, once you get the feeling, you will never be able to stop playing it.

This is a gem of my childhood. It was released in 2000, it was revolutionary back then. The technology now is far ahead though and Sacrifice has been forgotten.

Nevertheless, the game was (and still) is amazing.

• The plot is detailed. Features many deep characters, player choices, plot twists, several endings. A stranger in a mysterious world, you'll create your own unique story based on which gods you help and what critical decisions you make.

• The music is top notch. Fits the exotic climate in an unconventional fantasy theme.

• The voiceacting is outstanding.

• The gameplay: you summon an army that follows your lead and you get to cast spectacular spells that can even affect the terrain. You're after enemy wizard's altars.

• The combat: put amidst the chaos and madness you strive to eliminate the enemy forces while avoiding massive tornadoes, volcanos, eruptions and other insanities. You have to keep up with conjuring units as your army falls, but that takes time and you definitely want to be an asset with the powerful magic you wield.

The game might be old, but it's still an awesome purchase. I totally recommend it!

28788058.review:
Sacrifice is one of the defining titles of Shiny Entertainment, with all its pros and cons. By now it has become a classic.

You are a wizard serving one (or more) of five gods through events that will lead to the eventual destruction of their world. To help them you have two abilities: Spells and Summons.

Spells are what you expect, buffs, heals, damage, aoe... on later levels you can demolish the landscape and kill entire armies. Summons  give you access to a wide variety of different creatures, different for each god, some of which have cool abilities and none are looking generic. 

It is important to point out that is game is controlled like a third person RPG. The camera is fixed on your wizard and can be zoomed out, but not controlled individually. This takes some time getting used to since Sacrifice is, at its core, an RTS-Game.

Once you get used to the mechanics you can admire the awesome style, good writing and general good story.

27819531.review:
This game holds up surprisingly well - still looks decent even on a widescreen monitor, which is more than what can be said about a lot of games from the same era or even a few years later. The units and characters all have a very distinct look (although several models are re-used for a few different units), it's not all cookie-cutter humanoids everywhere like in most RTS you can see. It's definitely very refreshing.

The gameplay is great and very innovative, still feels pretty unique as there's not been any kind of sequel or competitor since then (Brutal Legend has some similarities, but the atmosphere is so different you cannot compare the two). One small "bad" thing about the soul mechanic is that every mission basically has a negative difficulty curve : you must beat back the enemy assault with your small initial force, and as you convert some of their souls each subsequent fight becomes easier. Doesn't prevent the game from being very fun to play.

The storyline is also pretty interesting, and the fact that you can choose a different god for (almost) every mission makes for good replayability - the campaign lasts 10 missions and 9 of those are different for each god, so that's a total of 45 different maps and scenarios to play through if you want to be torough (which I definitely recommend). The first missions seem to have almost no impact because they're minor (so even if you're not the one doing X, it will still happen) but as you progress in the story there's definitely major differences between, say, a Charnel playthrough versus a James one.

Cheap, often on sale (4,99€ as I'm writing this) and very enjoyable, there's really no reason to not get this if you remotely enjoy the RTS genre.

23907548.review: Even 16 years later, Sacrifice is still one of the most unique gaming experiences you can have. There have been similar forays in to the over-the-shoulder RTS genre, such as Battlezone, but Sacrifice isn't just an experiment in genre combination. The aesthetic, the control scheme, the dynamic terrain, the imaginitive units and spells, and the branching story are all gloriously ridiculous. The textures and models are dated, and it can be difficult to control large battles with the granularity that an RTS veteran might expect, but a small amount of patience on your part will be rewarded with a captivating and often quite funny campaign, and some robust multiplayer if you can find opponents. One of my top wishes for a remake.

This game has some of the most unique creatures I've ever played with in a game.  I've yet to see another game that manipulates the actual ground and sky you walk on like this game. The gods themselves have different and beautiful minions at their bidding and the music has stuck with me all these years.

22177444.review:
Sacrifice - рассказ о том, как могучий маг-некромант по имени Элдред, с манией величия и склонностью к тирании случайно погубил целый мир, а затем покинул его. Он пытается найти себе новый дом в новом мире. Почти весь игровой процесс протекает в виде повествования этого самого мага (если вы провалите миссию, то он говорит забавную фразу во время загрузки). Само повествование происходит в изуродованном, разваливающемся на части мире, в котором некогда бурлила настоящая жизнь. Не желая брать ответственность за разрушение очередного мира, Элдред решает покончить с причиной возникновения двух апокалипсисов. 
Точнее говоря, этим будет заниматься игрок. Перед ним предстанут 5 богов, с совершенно разными характерами. Выбор одного из них повлияет на многие параметры: от благосклонности остальных богов, до заклинаний, которые ему предоставят. 
Игровой процесс напоминает некую стратегию от третьего лица (с WASD управлением), что по сей день оставляет игру уникальной. Сложность миссий нарастает постепенно, отчего они могут длиться несколько часов! Любителей микроконтроля порадует боевая динамика.
Поддержка мультиплеера - присутствует, но только через эмуляцию LAN или через внешний IP. Игра с друзьями пройдет очень весело и азартно. 
Оцениваю игру как безупречную.
10 торнадо из 10

20159136.review:
Sacrifice is a beautiful, incredible, rich, and dangerously addicting game. The world oozes personality and its unique, almost alien charm will keep you coming back just to see what just might pop up next. With an all star voice cast a full decade before its likes could be considered the norm and gameplay unique but intuitive and natural, Sacrifice is a Real Time Strategy game like none other. Seeing it on Steam is like a dream come true, a truly innovative masterpiece of a game on the gold standard of online distribution services.

However, and it pains me to say this, you had best save your money. Sacrifice came out in the year 2000, and some systems may struggle to run it. I know mine did, and even now I experience crashes while loading the levels of this game. What's more, Steam's dashboard does not get along with Sacrifice, causing all manner of bugs and glitches whenever I bring it up. This review is to the game itself, however, and I would certainly advise more people to pick up Sacrifice, as it is a one of a kind experience, but it is not one currently optomized for Steam. I would advise those who enjoy this game to continue playing it and to share it and their experiences with others, and that those who have not played this game to try it and see for themselves just how amazing it is. I would also say that, in order for the consumers to truly get their money's worth, people look into updating Sacrifice, at least to the point where it can function within Steam.

18716865.review:
Sacrifice is a bit hard to describe. It's an older game so don't expect much from the graphics. Sacrifice is an army-focused spell-casting game. You play as a wizard that summons creatures to create an army and fight other wizards. Your character comes from a dying world to a new world with five gods. Your wizard introduces himself, and starts selecting which of the god's quests he wants to complete. 

What makes this game neat is that you can only choose 1 of the 5 quests, which makes that god like you more and the others dislike you, and the storyline spirals out from there. The same overarching storyline applies, but how you go about completing it and the way the story is told changes slightly depending on which god(s) you help. The five gods go from "Good" (Persephone) to "Evil" (Charnel), and it doesn't matter which one(s) you choose to do quests for. Besides the storyline shifting slightly, the god(s) you choose to assist will give you summon creatures and spells from their domain. For example, Persephone will give you healing spells that the other gods do not have, as well as Druids and Rangers, creatures only granted by Persephone. The game has a ton of re-playability because of the many combinations of choices you can make yielding entirely unique arsenals of creatures and spells for every playthrough. 

I highly recommend this game as a unique experience for gamers, even if "army-based strategy RPG" doesn't sound that appealing to you.

17621802.review:
"For Gamers by Gamers"- бессмертный лозунг давно почившей нас студии Interplay.

Моё знакомство как и у многих с этой игрой началось 1 мая 2000 года, из красочной статьи журнала "Страна Игр", в которой был подробный разбор всего, что есть в этой игре. Подобное невозможно забыть...
С чем-то сравнить данный шедевр  я не могу, ведь до сих пор так и не вышло ни одного достоиного ему в сравнение проекта и ввиду этого очень малое колличество читателей смогут понять о том что я сейчас скажу, если они сами не играли в это.

1) Сюжет

После скитания по постепенно исчезающим во мраке мирам, маг по имени Элдред, вступает в обитель пяти богов, каждый из которых правит той или иной силой бытия. Позже, в эти земли приходит некий оракул Митрас и гласит пророчество о пришествии новой силы, которая приведёт к падению нынешнего пантеона правителей и воцарится истинный порядок, именно этим и воспользовался наш главный герой.
Сюжет нелинеей, имеет множество поворотов и ряд концовок за каждую сторону конфликта по несколько штук, обзор всего действия происходит за каждую сторону и можно во время игры делать сюжетные переходы от одной фракции к другой- другими словами реиграбельность на все 100%.

2) Управление

Мы перемещаемся персонажем от 3-го лица по типичной схеме (WASD + Mousescroll). Всегда можно выбрать свой уровень обзора и уклона камеры, плюс, распределено много горячих клавиш для быстрого действия. И в этом главные минусы игровой системы:
1-вы не можете посмотреть на поле битвы за рамки обзора вашего героя
2-вы не способны выставить авто-зум или анти-блок камеры при перемещении
3-выделение юнитов и соединение их в отряды имеет ограничение по лимиту (это проблемы всех старых стратегий), обзор камеры конкретно влияет на то, как вы что-то хотите сделать и это не всегда получается. 
По сути, это не так серьёзно, но очень часто это может испортить игру, плюс , частые графические баги на этой почве, что сильно портит всё впечатление и атмосферу.
 
3) Геимплей, игровые элементы

Это стратегия от 3-го лица со всеми вытекающими: экономика, удержание позиций и рпг элементы; бой ведётся со стороны магов- слуг богов и у каждого, в зависимости от выбранной стороны, свои способности, которые делятся на: строительство , призыв и чары.Суть каждой партии это осквернение вражеского алтаря (уничтожение базы), либо конкретная миссия. Всего в игре есть два ресурса: души и мана- души для призыва юнитов, а мана это каст способностей, строительство и доп. стоимость призыва.
По ходу игры ваш герой будет получать уровни и с каждым новым открываются новые юниты, магия и здания.Также по ходу миссии можно получить благославение богов (улучшение для мага) и уникальных юнитов.
 Для получения душ надо убивать местных жителей и нейтралов или приносить в жертву души вражеских юнитов, некоторые здания обеспечивают прикрытие ,другие дают ману, а магия на усмотрение игрока . Но не смотря на простоту, каждая партия очень динамичная и сложная, так что тут поможет только опыт и умение.
Хотя, не всё так бодро и весело в плане сетевой игры... насладиться совместной игрой с друзьями можно только через сторонние програмы, по типу GameRanger, так как Steam не смогла создать достоиный сетевой порт, да и нынешние владельцы тоже.

4) Отд. элементы игры

В основу игры идёт идея божественной силы и самое главное- страха перед ней . В темноте нет ничего , чего стоит бояться- там лишь наши порождения, также и боги: они наши порождения и давать верх над нами им нельзя, наша судьба в наших руках, а искать высшую силу и уповать на неё- это безумия, узурпаторство и вечное унижение, жертвы и вот к чему это всё приводит...
Большая часть стиля игры была разработана исходя из работ нестандартной живописи, сюжета и арт-дизаина Эрика Фланнума (виновного в создании WarCraft 1/2/3, Diablo 1/2... это говорит о многом), ещё превосходный актёрский состав (Тим Кёрри и Бред Геррет), лучшие на то время 3D технологии и инновационый код движка, который теперь состоит в каждом исходнике новой скелетной анимации.   

В целом, это всё что можно сказать; очень мало, но для большей картины стоить хотя-бы поиграть в неё самому. Есть ещё много аспектов, но на все не хватит обзора, да и главное, базовые элементы я уже рассказал.

Вывод: самый неординарный и прогрессивный проект своего (и нашего ) времени, не получивший ни славы, ни продолжения... но занимающий место в сердце, для меня это главное 9/10!


Буду рад усышать вменяемою критику, советы или просто одобрение. Удачи всем и хороших игр на распродаже!

14528019.review:
Sacrafice is a great game.  If there's ever been a "overlooked game that deserves a sequal" it's this one.

The graphics actually hold up still, they were absolutely the top of the line at the time is likely why.  The only thing that bugged me in a recent replaythrough about them was ingame there isn't lipsync.  That said, the gods themselves have prerendered animation that looks great still.

Recognize the protagonist's voice?  Yeah, he's the guy who did the voice of the warrior in the first Diablo and Aldaris in Starcraft.  Yeah, he's badass.  Also one of the gods is voiced by TIm Curry.

Something a lot of people might overlook is the world has some incredible lore put into it.  It feels like it might be a game out of a long standing fantasy book series, but it's not.  The game is also home home to one of the biggest plot twists in gaming.

If it has any faults, its that the difficulty is a bit uneven.  Some levels are stupid hard, some don't challenge you at all.  The RTS elements have some faults, I personally find it hard to do all the actions they set out to have.  It's generally easier to jsut have all your creatures guard you and sweep the field than it is to strategically move units around the map.  Things are a bit too fast paced for advanced strategy and it want to be near your units to collect their souls when they die too.

That said, tenattaten, 10/10, best game, best game.

Sacrifice is a game that is old, but still looks good and is perfectly playable, even online.
It is a third person perspective... RTS game :)
You play as a sorcerer who can summon creatures, order them to follow, move, attack, etc.
Your units are very unique and the best part is, they are given to you by the gods, that give you certain missions.
If you work against certain gods, you can forget about their units, but you get others instead.
And they don't behave the same, they have different skills... You can often alternate or even redeem yourself in the eyes of  angered gods, which allows for a very replayable game.
The resources for summons are souls, which can be re-used for your creatures, or captured, for enemy creatures.
The AI are good, that makes the game hard. Very, very hard :)

I highly recommend this game.

12198470.review:
One of the best games of all time. Many of you will skim over this because you've never heard of it, because none of your friends play it or because of its sparse store page. You shouldn't.

Sacrifice offers the best mix of tactical depth and ease of learning I have ever seen in a strategy game. You play as a wizard standing down on the field where everything happens. Any units you summon are summoned directly next to you, buildings are created only by you standing next to them (for up to 10 seconds for the largest buildings), and orders are given based on what you can personally see. This makes for a much more immersive and easy-to-grasp gameplay than most other strategy games out there where you may be queuing up orders, units and buildings; might be zoomed far enough out  to be disconnected from the world but not far enough out to see any useful distance.

Furthermore, the wizards you can choose from in multiplayer (you always play as Eldred in the fully-voiced campaign) are all equal. That is, everyone you might play against has access to the exact same spells and units as you. Or rather they have access to the same choices: your spell and unit lists are fully customizable offering a massive amount of variation possible. You could have ranged units that damage over time, can go invisible, can track enemies etc. Or you could pick units based on style if you prefer and do just fine: disease-ridden monsters, aloof mythical creatures, rangers, soldiers, constructs...

This customisation is in the campaign too but in a much more organic style so that you won't have to worry about choosing units based on no previous experience. Every level of the game has 5 alternatives (one for each of the gods) and each god will try to convince you the help them for each mission. You can decide who to help on a mission-by-mission basis, picking the most interesting or beneficial mission for you. You can become unwaveringly loyal to a particular god (or a certain alliance between 2 or more gods) and only server them. Or you can decide completely randomly if you like. Every mission you take increases your pool of spells or units equally, with units and spells granted by the god you choose to work for. You can also pick up heroes along the way who will be loyal to you (unless you do something completely against their nature) and will follow you in future missions until they die or you lose their trust. Every mission you choose (and don't choose) affects future levels to varying degrees. By making a god's defence stronger you protect their territory that another god or being was after and would've been able to use in future levels. Discovering something allows the god you discovered it for use that information in future battles. Capturing a village, building, character, area etc. will give the benefits of that asset to your god (whether that be a new factory, new allies, a weakness in another god or a number of other boons). This all leads to your character and the world evolving organically in a way that's not always obvious but always makes sense. By the end of your fifth mission you'll have access to a wide variety of spells and units (and perhaps a hero or two) and certain gods will have grown or diminished in power noticeably.

All of the spells are breathtaking. From the bog-standard heal and speed-up spells you begin with which create a pleasant glow/melody and a cool-looking trail effect respectively. To the more extreme spells granted later on including tornados, volcanos, earthquakes, death-incarnate and many more. In addition, most of these spells can be cast within a couple of seconds and without stopping. This allows you to run amidst your army healing, speeding up and buffing who you need, sniping an important enemy unit (or a bunch of them) and then hiding behind your own units again within a very short period of time. A lot of these spells (and some units) scare the landscape permanently too. This makes places where small skirmishes and large battles have occurred very obvious, even after 5, 10 or 60 minutes. Scorch marks, blood stains, unnatural bumps or dips in the earth, sometimes even the earth itself has gone.

The penultimate thing will mention (even though there is so much more I could say) is that the humour in this game is incredible from start-to-finish. From the gods (voiced by Brad Garrett, Kevin Michael  Richardson, Castulo Guerra, Jennifer Hale and Tim Curry) to the units (every one of which with the sole exception of the manahor (an armless, mana-dispensing bunny) has a half-dozen lines if you enjoy clicking on a unit repeatedly long enough for it to yell at you to get lost) to the wizards. This game has so much personality and not in an annoying way.  The humor interlaces with the rest of the game beautifully instead of being forced like in so many other games.

Lastly, this game is worth your money and time without question. Without exaggeration I have played through the campaign seven times with a vastly different playthrough and experience each time: once following each of the gods wholeheartedly, once working for all of the gods and keeping them all as friendly with me as possible for as long as possible and once attempting to keep a pair of gods powerful and friendly with each other until the end.

At £7 it's worth it easily, at half-price (as it is at the time of this review) I can't recommend it more to everyone I know. Get it, it's awesome.

-Edit- There isn't much more I can say about this game before I nominate it. It's great, get it now.

11604527.review:
Would I completely recommend this game? It depends if you want to support a diverse gaming industry. I find that when games try to give the player more control over what goes from seeming complicated to simple in a small amount of time that the learning curve is an easy one, but makes the gameplay all the better. I'm a big fan of RTS games that allow for individual FPS control (think starcraft but you could control a single marine, or a pyro, and when you die you become the guy next to him). This wasn't exactly the case, but doesn't meant I can appraise the game for what it is.

Sacrifice's storyline itself is good. In fact it's great that I won't talk about it because if your really into story telling of four gods duking it out waging wars with one another and you being the catalyst, you might like this. The gameplay itself I like for the reason the game designers had the intentions of making a FPS RTS game, they tried pushing boundaries. This game back in the day may have been phenominal, but today the gameplay leaves me to hunger for a bit more. You are a sorcerer of sorts able to casts spells to build certain buildings (mana places or soul collecting places for troops) and build units around those buildings and replenish your mana faster. Over the course of the game you come across units and similar buildings to yours, which of course you have to attack commanding your units or by your magic. Different units allow for different purposes. Mana horns I learned early on that you need them to replenish mana in the field (after dying several times... probably should have read a tutorial but ain't nobody got time for one longer than a minute)! The control scheme as well I find is easy. The only thing I would really like if they allowed you to zoom out furhter on the character.

I will give this game a .9 instead of a .7 due to it trying to break more boundaries. I find games like this allow gaming to go beyond graphics, but start looking at gameplay again (be it single player, coop, or multiplayer. They all have their own joy to offer). 

RATING : 7.6/10

11353737.review:
Hey, it's that one guy! You'll be saying that a lot as you play through this game. The outstanding voice-over work includes Tim Curry (Stratos), Tony Jay (Mithras), Paul Eiding (Eldred), and Brad Garrett (James), among others. The script they are given to work with is pretty good, too; the five squabbling gods are full of character. It's hard to pick your favorite.

Imagine Brütal Legend actually had some depth to its units and you have Sacrifice in a nut-shell. What units you get depend on which god you decide to follow for that particular mission, allowing you to mix and match units and spells for the first half of the game, allowing for a different experience each time you play through the story. And you'll want to play through it more than once; each god has a very different approach to the story as well as several unique missions.

This game is one of the best games to come out of the early 2000s. It's a shame that it doesn't have very much visibility; if you haven't played this game, pick it up.

9974918.review:
Despite being 14 years old this game has aged very well. The fact that the world and the creatures look like something designed by Hieronymus Bosch is part of the reason why this game still looks unique and interesting. But the voice acting is also very well done. In fact if you look up the IMDB page with the voice cast of this game it reads like a who's who of voice acting. If you've been watching cartoons or playing games in the past fifteen years there's a good chance you've heard their voices many, many times. Tim Curry is probably the most well known, but veteran voice actors like Tony Jay and Michael Bell (Legacy of Kain), Tara Strong (Harley Quinn in recent Batman games and cartoons), Dwight Schultz (Murdock on the A-team and Luitenant Barclay on several Star Trek shows), Frank Welker (Megatron in the movies and the cartoon series) and Rob Paulsen (Yakko from Animaniacs, Stanley Ipkiss from Mask) are just a few of the actors that deliver the voices heard throughout the game. 
The game is also a lot of fun to play. It's a real time strategy game where you are a wizard who has been driven from his own universe and is now a drifting mercenary for hire. Each level you can choose one of five gods to work for and this god will grant you two of their minions to summon and spells to cast. This makes for great replayability because all the minions have different strengths and weaknesses. Because some of these gods hate each other working for one god will make other gods dislike you. So if you choose the same god several times some of the other gods won't be available. 
Once you start a level you'll need manna to cast spells and souls to cast creatures. Each level is a tug of war between you and several other wizards who are all trying to grab as many souls and as many mana fountains as they can. Only by destroying the altar of an enemy wizard you can really vanquish him from the area. This makes for some frantic gameplay where the tide of battle can suddenly take a change for the worst.
Shiny also infused the game with their unique sense of humor. For instance each time you cast a spell you'll hear your wizard shout out some magic words. Some of these sound a lot like "klatuu barada nikto" a command used in the classic scifi movie "The Day the Earth Stood Still" (1951) which is often referenced in games and movies (like in Evil Dead 3 where Bruce Campbell has to use these words as a spell to calm down the Necronomicon). But there's also a spell which will summon a huge cow which will crash down like a meteorite and create a large crater. One of the gods (Stratos) has a head painted on a balloon comming out of a bottle of helium and James (the god of earth) looks a lot like earthworm Jim.
After a while most battles will feel similar because the basic strategy never changes. But there's an interesting story being told in between the levels and the constant addition of new spells and creatures helps to keep things fresh. The game got rave reviews but didn't sell well. So back then I bought it cheap and had a lot of fun playing it.

9165589.review:
PLAY IT

This fantastic Action-RTS hybrid (which amazingly was released in 2000) is a spiritual predecessor to Brutal Legend, but as far as the RTS mechanics go it plays more like a faster, more furious Warcraft III, another game it preceded by a fair amount. It's built on the tried-and-true Melee/Ranged/Flyer triangular counter system and focuses on a central unit, the wizard, which gains experience levels and new spells as the match or mission progresses. 

There are no goldmines or forests to exploit, however, the only resources on the field are manafounts, which, once built upon, can relay mana to you and your army. To build units, you use souls, which are painstakingly converted from heathens, including enemy military units. Since you're feeding on your enemy, you can either chip away at the enemy army in a passive game of zoning and area denial, cut down his mana supply by harrassing his manaliths, or you can just strike at the jugular and attempt to kill the wizard in a battle royale, severely reducing the potential of his units if successful. Despite the strategic simplicity of the game, all RTS playstyles are accounted for.

Sacrifice is a third-person view game centered on the player, not top-down view like a traditional RTS. The camera is notorious for not zooming out a lot - the wizard is advised to seek high ground so he may properly command his forces. Control groups help a ton. The interface is extensive and highly-customizable, but it'll probably take a lot of playing before you're making use of all the shortcuts.

There's an all-star cast of voice actors and they're all in their element here. The soundtrack is memorable and no game element seems odd or out of place, as bizarre and surreal as the game world is. The grotesque monsters, the meaty ground, the strange plants and structures, the whole aesthetic of the game comes together so well.

If I had to criticize one thing about the game, I'd have to criticize its competitive value. The game is better-suited for tournaments than many RTS but there are a lot of random elements that plague the player, particularly the random nature of melee attack damage and certain endgame spells and units. Speaking of the endgame, the final levels of the campaign and the credits seem a bit rushed in comparison to the tons of love given the early missions.

No matter what you're looking for in a classic game, I'm pretty certain you'll find it here. You cannot truly experience this game on the first playthrough. The lore is deep, the gameplay is deep, and the crevasses between the floating islands that make up the world are deep. If a flier is shot down over the abyss, his soul is lost forever. ;_;7

8988021.review:
This is one of the best games I have ever played. Unique mixture of RPG/RTS/TPS, which doesn't feel like almost any other game. You are a wizard, who comes to a new world and is being offered to serve multiple gods, totally 5 of them, which one you will pick is your choice and each of them has its own distinguishable personality + the voice acting is just excellent! With names like Tim Curry, Brad Garrett and Jennifer Hale.

The gameplay self revolves around collecting souls that enables you to create your own units and capturing manaliths that gives you mana regeneration to cast spells and summon creatures. The objectives vary in campaign, but is mostly  focused on defeating enemy Sorcerer by desecrating their altars (casting Desecrate spell on own unit and killing enemy sorcerer), since if you only kill them, then they can ressurect.

Every time you choose to play mission in campaign, you have to pick which god you are going to side with, which grants you either specific creature/spell of that god or both, meaning each god has 9 Creatures and 9 Spells that you can combine. Some creatures and spells have similar concepts, but each has specific visuals and/or twist, which provides huge variety and replayability, although I personally think Pyro is the most powerful one.

The campaign also provides interesting story with some quite nice twists, it's indeed not the anything extremely extrodinary, but I still like the story regardless. The best part is that you can side with different gods with each gameplay, thus playing from different point of view, making it look like multiple different storylines. Every god has also specific personality, based off elements. Nature/Life + Ground/Rocks/Earth + Air/Ice + Fire/Machines/Technology + Death/Decay.

The graphics looks quite good for it's time (2000!), especially thanks to the character designs I've talked about earlier, but Sacrifice was also one of first games to use anti-aliasing, terrain change and other advanced technologies, which actually makes it feel more like 2004-2006 game, which is quite an extrodinary achievement, so kudos to developers.

Still, despite being accepted extremely well by critics and being called one of the best games of the year, the game didn't sell well. It probably was due to many factors, but one of the main ones would be that it was quite performance depending game and only top PC setups of its time could run it propetly, making it sort of Crysis of its time, thus the actual market for the game quite tiny and the Shiny (company that developed Sacrifice) ended up in huge losses and never recovered, which is personally kind of ironic, since I consider this one of best games ever made to this day.

In conclusion, Sacrifice is worth not only playing, but also replaying. It is one of most unique games that works flawlessly, the designs looks amazing and characters are extremely memorable, with great writing and voice acting, it is a gem that we should treasure, not only for its quality, but also for the efford it took everyone to make it. The developers put everything they had into this game and I only wish they had opportunities to make more great games. So buy and play this game, because it actually has, I dare to say it, soul!

8580330.review:
One of my favourite games of all time (this is my third copy of the game) which I've owned for many years outside of Steam, this one makes a wonderful blend between RTS and RPG with amazing voice acting (especially for the time).

Be it a frantic murderball trying to stomp everything around you or carefully sending packs of troops to flank your opponent's manaliths, there are many stratagies that can work for you.

A great formation system allows you to keep your ranged troops behind while your melee takes the brunt of the enemy forces, but beware! Friendly fire is always on, so your ranged troops might hit some of your own!

The storyline has one ending but multiple paths you can pursue, with some missions being incredibly challenging while others are a breeze to go through so expect some variation if you choose to be the vassal of different gods in your playthroughs.

My only complaint about this game is that there is no sequel or remake.

8571480.review:
I bought this game for $1.50 while during one of Steam's sales. I had wanted it previously but with so many other games available it took a back seat.

For the day, this was supposed to be a kick ass game, which earned it plenty of accolades by various critics. Even IGN named it "strategy game of the year" but it still financially failed miserably.  Some critics said players needed a third hand or extra fingers.

I must agree. While the game strategy is awesome, the game interface is awkward and cumbersome. There is no way to get a clear view of the battle from behind the wizard, which reminded me of Dead Space. 

With voice acting of Tim Curry and music by Kevin Manthei, one would think the game would excel. Even the art work and graphics, light years ahead for the day, couldn't make up for the crappy controls.

Well worth the $1.50 I paid to get those nostalgic memories, I instantly became bored and haven't played it since. Maybe multiplayer versions are more fun, but the single player version leaves a lot to be desired.

2/5 stars.

8419731.review:
If you like Action, MOBA, RTS and RPGs then this game is for you! This older title (2000) has a unique style of RTS game-play (resource gathering--collecting souls and building--summoning minions) and the game-play feels similar to some games of the MOBA genre, e.g. Smite. The single player campaign has hours of replay because each missions is selected from pool of five choices that result in different selections, which either lock or unlock missions based on player decisions.  Although the Steam Store doesn't show multiplayer available for this game it is and multiplayer is one of the best parts of the game!

In Sacrifice multiplayer you can choose one of the preset casters that correspond with the gods in the single player campaign: fire mage, earth mage, necromancer, air mage, life mage or you can complete the single player campaign and use your custom mage (each level in single player grants a new spell and those spells differ based on which god you serve).

Sacrifice was ahead of its time. If you can get past the graphics, you'll love the game-play and the single player storyline.

I heard a fair bit about this game and even played a demo many, many years ago and decided to give it a little run.
Of course, given it's age, you can't really exspect it to have great graphics. Neither did I. The animations aren't actually half bad for the outdated engine.
The idea of the game, combining a RTS with this unusual view, the unique resource 'souls', the whole aspect of how to beat an enemy player (by blocking their altar)... Nice!
And even has an interesting story for the singleplayer.

However, a thing that really pose an issue to me is the clunky controls. Commanding units is a pain and you'll often not know whether you actually send them at the target you intended to click (mostly due to the perspective reasons). Movement feels like a different era (probably is), overall gameplay feels not all too interesting (singleplayer pretty much comes down to luring the enemy into a trap to snatch some souls, rinse&repeat until you got enough to crush him near his altar).

I will not doubt this was a unique and milestone-ish game at one point, but measured with today's standards, it just can't cope (gameplay/controls-wise, I do not judge it for it's graphics).

This Game got me good. Even though it's almost ancient (It was released in 2000), it has really awesome thoughts put into it. The idea of this game is fantastic, yet it's a bit hard, since you only have that 3rd person perspective with sort of crappy camera adjustments. However, it sure is a Game worth playing: Magic in this game is something I'd considder *REAL Magic*, I haven't seen any game with that sort of magic concept such as in Sacrifice, since it's really affects the environment or is 'realisticly' big. A summoned Tornado, for example, is roughly the game characters size multiplied by 255. It's fantastic to look at that. Furthermore, the Game itself has gigantic potential. I personally hope for a improved remake of this game.
Pro vs Cons:
+Great replay value as mentioned everywhere; Due to the campaign.
+Great Concept and Ideas.
+Unique Troops. And I've seen lots. 
+Awesome Spellcasting. By far the most awesome part in the whole game.
+Differences between races/elements is good.
+Entertaining, as you can influence the slightest flow of battle.
~Challenging. My longest battle till now was 'round 12 Minutes of non-stop summoning/spelling stuffs.
~Amass of Species: There is enough for everything, but there could be "more". More Maps for skirmishes, maybe levelable summons, things like that. Maybe even a skill-tree for your wizard.
- Camera Angles: Can often disturb the scenery, also there's only 3rd Person, as far as I have played.
- Ressource-Management: There could be some sort of other way to gain Souls; Since if you lose an important battle, you basically lose the match, as you lose all your gathered souls to your enemy, except if you were agile enough to gather them during battle.

Once you get past all the creepy discussion about souls, desecration, etc, this game is fun. 

Some hotkey controls would make a big difference, and maybe a little more information about the units abilities, other than that this is $2 well spent. 

Sacrifice offers a nice variation on the usual, top down real-time strategy game. I don't usually play RTS games, resource races and clicking contests. So far Sacrifice avoids those pitfalls with emphasis on unit choice, formation, and position...you know...strategy. 

Sacrifice also doesn't require every decision to be made at blazing speed, which is nice, so you can take a moment to regroup, spawn some things, re-position, and re-engage. This softening of the real-time aspect also makes the game more enjoyable.

This is probably a little too casual for the hardcore RTS types, and the old-school nature of it limits the graphics, storyline, and unit choices, but its a cool game and for $2 you can't ask for much more.

8003248.review:
Have you ever played Brutal Legend? If yes, have you heard of Sacrifice? Assuming not, Sacrifice IS one of the first and the best Action RTS hybrid titles out there, so BL's gameplay is hardly all that "innovative" (though still fun). Fun fact: Tim Curry starred in both of those games. You don't know who Tim Curry is? Go sit in the corner, you're on timeout.

Sacrifice is an incredibly bizzare and twisted game. Probably the weirdest I've ever played, aside from American McGee's Alice and The Path. The game sounds fantastic, has got a very memorable soundtrack and the voice acting is simply superb. The world and the creatures that inhabit it are quite strange, but unique and beautiful in their own way. The graphics are pretty outdated in this one though and it's something that may be difficult to overlook, especially if you're having a hard time getting engrossed into the game.

The gameplay is something that takes time to get used to and playing the (rather comprehensive and enjoyable) tutorial is a must here. As previously mentioned, it's a third person squad based game where you make formations out of your units, cast spells to aid them in battle and complete various map objectives. Whatever units and spells you acquire vastly depends on the deities you choose as the story progresses, thus making the game replayable due to the large amount of combinations that can be created. 

Last but not least, game has the same oddball sense of humor you might find in titles like Earthworm Jim. Considering that Earthworm Jim was the first successful creation of (now defunct) Shiny Ent. along with Sacrifice that followed a few years later, it's not all that surprising.

This game is really, horribly underrated. But at the same time, it's not for everyone. If you enjoy the hybrid gameplay of games like Brutal Legend, Overlord or Natural Selection (to name a few, but those three are on Steam), you might as well give Sacrifice a chance.

7813364.review:
A wizard fleeing from a land torn asunder, his past tinted a bloody red, finds succour in a land on the eve of war. A pawn of the gods, or chaos itself? Or perhaps no pawn at all...

Imagine a world without the internet. Imagine being alone in a room with a computer, and no internet, for several hours a day. Perhaps some of you don't need to imagine, perhaps some of you still live a life away from the madness of the net, able to sequester yourself in an insular paradise. Well, if that is the case, or perhaps you need to forget the world for a few hours and a lifetime, I honestly have to recommend Sacrifice.

I bought this game back in 2002, the first year of uni, and I have to say for about 4-6 hours of every day - before I met up with my friends, this was my world. I suppose I should have been a better student, studied more and achieved better grades. But it's very rare to be able to look *back* at a time, and say while it mightn't have been the best use of the time, you don't regret it. This game was that much fun.

Later on it was joined by staples such as Wizardry 8 and fps's i'm sure we've all played, but even throughout the next two years of my life, it still earnt its place on the shelf. It's just...an amazing game. It is still beautiful, the insane character models defying time, the gameplay still challenging and sometimes even frustrating, the spells still awesome, the gods still scheming and the action as frantic as ever.

I have yet to play a game that really catches up to Sacrifice. Like a lot of great innovative games, at the time it just didn't get to its audience. Like your system shocks or deus ex's, where decades have passed before they've been emulated and resurrected, Sacrifice fits into a niche that is hard to define. You play like a field marshall, summoning troops to your side even as you dodge incoming fire and fury, and your objective is often simply to conquer, to destroy, to cleanse. But the path to that goal is often turf-war, sneak attacks, flanking, trap-setting and straight bull-dozing through your enemies. It's a wild and wonderful ride, with an atmosphere that pulls you in almost from the first moment.

I can't recommend it enough.

2017870.review:
If you read any list of "games that should have sold a lot better than they did" then it is likely that Sacrifice will be somewhere on it. This is a game that was ahead of its time in several aspects - player choice, voice acting and simple gameplay.

Sacrifice is something of a cross between a strategy game and an action-RPG. You control a wizard, and you can summon troops, cast spells and summon buildings across the map. This sounds like pretty standard fare, but the context of the single player campaign is what brings it to the next level; there are five competing gods, any of whom you can side with from mission to mission. The spell(s) and creature(s) you unlock depends upon which god you sided with on each mission, and is permanent for that playthrough. Of course, do enough to piss off a specific god and they will no longer be prepared to deal with you, and towards the latter stages of the campaign you are forced to lock-in your final choice anyway, as events reach their climax. I mentioned voice acting, and the gods in Sacrifice are the main source - my personal favourite - Charnel, the god of death - has some cracking lines and jibes at the others.

In this day and age, Sacrifice is going to be a bit dated - hell it came out in the year 2000, but for a few quid this is really one of those hidden gems from gaming history.

P.S my playtime on Steam is pretty low because I bought the original CD version back when it came out.

Sacrifice was (and still is), an amazing game and deserves all the recognition it can get! 

The mechanics of the game (even to this day), are fresh and exciting. The gameplay of Sacrifice is as follows: an RTS/RPG, where you play as a wizard who controls an impressive array of spells and units with the end goal of eliminating rival factions and their wizards. Boasting an indepth, lengthy campaign complete with many conceptionally creative units, factions, heroes, Gods and lands, Sacrifice is a game chalk full of content. Sacrifice is also a treat for both the eyes and the ears as the game boasts amazing visuals, textures, audio, music, and character voice overs with some influential and well known actors - such as Tim Robbins & Tim Curry. While the mechanics of the game are interesting and varied, the control scheme may take a bit of getting used to (damn that locked camera!), but have no fear, once you master the camera and unit formations, the game becomes oh so much more enjoyable.

Pick up this extremely underrated masterpiece for only $10, as it's absolutely worth every penny!

There is a realm, outside our own, where magical beasties and misfits from all legend and imagination live, and five supreme gods watch over--and commomly intervene--this literally shattered world. Their embassies, Wizards, are their greatest followers, and most destructive weapons: casting powerful feats, protection, but also curses, and agony. 113953.review:
Tied with Deus Ex as my most favorite game ever. Sacrifice is an action/strategy hybrid game where you play a wizard who fights for the favor of 5 gods (who constantly fight among themselves). Summon creatures, issue them orders, buff them with defensive spells or cast offensive spells to destroy enemies. Claim the souls of your fallen foes in order to summon more units for your own army, then push your enemy back to their altar, and sacrifice a minion to destroy it, banishing the enemy wizard from the world and preventing them from respawning.

Fight for the gods:
Persephone, godess of nature, order and healing, 
James, god of earth, stone and peace, 
Stratos, god of air, cold and knowledge, 
Pyro, god of fire, chaos and industry, or 
Charnel, god of death, plague and suffering.

Stick with one god to get all their toys or build an army of mixed units from certain combinations of gods to exploit their unique advantages. This game has a large, branching campaign and great multiplayer.
